reviewText:
Oh blimey, what happened here? It's as if someone took Postal, took all the weapons out, mixed it with Goat simulator, baked a rather crudely made cake out of it and then merely added Lucius as the glazing!

But in all seriousness, this is quite terrible. Yes, the first game was quite limited, but it was a solid game with a fairly dense athmosphere and kills that had some weight and meaning to them.
In Lucius 2, meanwhile, you're pointlessly killing braindead NPCs who just happen to be around. Mostly with poisoned doughnuts, because the game mechanics are far too wonky and buggy to actually try and plot some kind of ingenious way of dispatching somebody.

Poisoned doughnuts, you ask? Why yes, haven't i mentioned the braindead AI? Why WOULDN'T you eat an entire box of doughnuts that you randomly found on the floor? And while we're at it, why WOULD you react to that little boy over there, bursting into demonic flames as he levels up? Clearly, this game is supposed to take place in some bizarro-dimension.

Oh, it also doesn't help that when you do achieve such an unsatisfying, anticlimactic kill, the game demonstrates just how crudely it's made with a display of wonky, silly ragdoll physics. Whoo.

Have i mentioned that on top of all of that bad design, the game is also one of the buggiest messes i've seen? Yeah, NPCs phasing through doors, objects becoming non-interactable at random, the whole shabang. There's quite a few early access games out there that are more finished than this one. At least at the time of writing, which is 2 days after release.

reviewText:
Lucius II is a GREAT game. The plot makes sense, there's a decent amount of content and replayability, it's a beautifully atmospheric game and it stands alone in its style. All in all, I'd give this game an 8/10. What Lucius II tries to achieve, it achieves fairly effectively. There's a few bugs and problems, but considering the enormity of the game, it's to be expected, and none of the bugs are particularly ground-breaking.

Personally I'd price it at around $15, so grab it at a discount if you can. However, the developers seem really committed to updating and patching Lucius II, and the game definitely has a unique style to it (that I for one love). If you'd like to see a Lucius III, I definitely would say that you won't be too disappointed paying full price for the game, and you'll help contribute to a sequel :)

I've broken down my review into positives, slight negatives and big negatives as follows. I'd weigh up each of the following before deciding if you'd like to buy the game or not:

POSITIVES:

- Much more content to explore than the original game! The hospital ward plus the town of Ludlow total roughly three times the size of the mansion in the original!

- A controllable and customisable level-up system - choose how to progress your skills!

- SO much customisation and interactability with the environment. You can combine some items with other items to create complex traps for potential victims, as well as use some items with objects in the environment for the victims to interact with.

- A plethora of ways to kill victims. The original game was incredibly limited, but in Lucius II you'll never be short of potential ways to hunt your victims down!

- Due to the number of ways to kill victims, replayability is definitely an option!

- Full and working controller support! No more mapping keys to buttons!

- Achievements that were much more thought out than in the original: certain hours of gameplay and travelling specific distances are a thing of the past!

- Collectibles that you can hunt down!

SLIGHT NEGATIVES:

- A nitpick, but there are both spelling and grammar errors in both the subtitles and the in-game descriptions (while playing in English). The audio sometimes is slightly different to the subtitles.

- I encountered a few objects or items that simply said '[TEXT DESCRIPTION]', so I'm guessing the developers forgot to code in some of the text. This doesn't affect functionality in any way.

- For whatever reason, when I started up, the default subtitle size was set to 0.0 instead of 1.0, so I couldn't even read the subtitles at first. I don't know if this is hard-coded into the game, or specific to me, but for a professional game this shouldn't be a problem.

- The first level is next to impossible to kill everyone in for the 'Problem Child' achievement due to an extremely limited number of potential ways to kill the mental patients.

- There's a few glitches. Occasionally you'll come across a door that doesn't open, but you simply pass through. Occasionally electricity or a cord will take on a mind and physics of its own, though this doesn't affect gameplay at all, just the visuals.

BIG NEGATIVES:

- KEYS. I love the concept of gathering keys to unlock areas, but there's a serious problem with them. Occasionally, they'll disappear once you reload a save without collecting them. If you save over your original save, there's no way to get them back, and you are sometimes left unable to complete a level. Considering this game relies a lot of save-and-load, you're bound to run into this at least once.

- While the total area you can explore is indeed more than in Lucius, the areas are *entirely* level-specific. In the original, it was always the same mansion, perhaps with slightly more areas available each level. In Lucius II, each level is independent.

- Serious kill-mechanic oversights. There's so many brilliant ways to kill victims, but I found myself not even hunting them out, as every level after the first is far too EASY. This is mostly due to Mind Control regenerating power on a successful kill, and an over-powered item. I've summarised these in spoilers for you, in case you don't want to read about the 'easy kills':

Once you unlock mind control, you can basically get every single person in the first chapter to simply walk down an elevator shaft. The developers limited the number of times you can do this (which was a great idea), but they forgot about fire. Kill someone with fire, then mind-control another victim and have them walk over the first victim's burning corpse. The second victim will die, and also catch on fire. This fire lasts around a minute, and resets the timer if you kill another victim. I managed to pile up over 30 victims from the result of one initial flame!

The nailgun is over-powered. One shot is an instant kill, and it comes with 5 shots per pack of nails. There's even a second pack of nails right by the gun when you first find it, giving you 10 shots. If that's not enough, at the start of chapter 2 there's another 15 nails for you to collect, giving a total of 25 possible kills from the nailgun alone.

Unstable. Many, many bugs. Save states are amateur level in that they'll save the status of some objects and objectives and not others.

Sometimes you can load from a save, other times you cannot. It's the luck of the draw whether or not a save will be loadable at all. No idea how they managed this trainwreck after a passable game the first time around, but this seems like it was made by complete newbie developers.

As for the non-technical aspects, the gameplay is passable enough when it isn't breaking, the writing is horrible, there are typos and grammar mistakes in the menus. I'm surprised this was made by the same team responsible for the original Lucious, a game I enjoyed and that ran and performed just fine.

Maybe it will be fixed, but there's no way in hell you should be buying something this horrendously broken before it's confirmed it's playable.

Really disappointed, but given the glut of unfinished, broken games lately, not surprised at all.

Skip it.

reviewText:
Lucius 2 begins at the end of Lucius 1. The detective saves you from the burning house, you end up in a hospital, here you attack a nun, get thrown into isolation and kill your doctors. here starts the actual gameplay, where you have to escape the hospital.

Pros:
+Lots of ways to kill people, you are no longer restrained to kill a person the same way. this might seem like only 1 + point, but this has great impact on your game experience and will make you wanna play more than 1 playthrough as you can take a different path now.
+more maps, and bigger. there are like 10 maps, and each has lots of people in it (especially the maps in the hospital and in the town)
+ More abilities, tree perk. you no longer only have 1 or 2 abilities you can use like in lucius. we were only able to create fire in the last few moments of the game, so you could max kill 3 people with the most awesome abilty.. however, in lucius 2 because of the tree perks you can decide what abilities you want first, (there are 3 tree perks, each has a few more powers in it as you level it up, you can have 2 full tree's when you complete the game)
+Graphics are slightly better, but this doesnt matter that much for most people.

now lets talk cons.
-Lucius 2 has a bad story, this is something everyone can agree on. the beginning makes sense and is alright. but as you move forward, and complete the town map, you get the feeling they just send you to random blunt maps which seem the same and kinda boring looking

-its hard to understand at first. before the game begins you get this little tutorial which gives you lots of information in a few minutes, which you quickly forget as some powers you wont immediately use. in lucius 1 the powers were evenly spread and when you got a new power / ability it was clearly explained how to use it and when, this however was not the case in lucius 2. (i had to look up a guide for the first map, so i understood how i could do everything and where to look for hints etc.)

-the people in this game are absolutely ridiculous. you can kill someone in front of a nurse and she wont even come of her chair. you can break/modify items and people staring at you wont stop you. the only way to make them move is to actually walk in a restricted area, and even then is their line of sight really bad so you dont ever have the feeling of being truly ♥♥♥♥ed. also when you do get busted you can just use a lifeline and go on again, youll lose a bit of health but its easily gained by visiting a toilet (which are everywhere in this game)

Okay, lets get real here for a second: Lucius 2 does not exceed the expectations after playing Lucius 1 for alot of people, the story is worse, AI is terrible, the people react bad, but that doesnt mean that this is such a bad game.

Lucius 2 is a fun game to cycle around with your tricycle as you kill people with anything that you can touch. (or mind control) it might not be the most realistic or serious game but thats okay. Cause its fun.

Id rate this game a 7/10 for enjoyment. as its really original with its playstyle. you wont often play something thats like this. i do recommend buying this on sale though. since the worth of the game really depends on what you find important in a game.

reviewText:
What in the heck happened to this game? I didn't have to play long to see the many problems it has.

I enjoyed the first game and while it had limitations, at least npcs felt more real to me than those in this game. The NPCs at first were jumping/glitching all over the place when I first started playing and for a second I thought I was lagging or something. Turns out it was the game itself to my surprise.

Some of the stuff, while a little creative, has me questioning why people would pick up donuts off the floor and eat them? Unknowningly to them, the donuts were poisoned and  it was followed by a horrible choking animation and slight ragdoll flail to the floor. Needless to say, what happened?

Not only that, sometimes I try to over think it and try to make a smart trap and turns out it doesn't work, or at least I thought. I then gave up on it and went half across the map to do something else, but then suddenly my screen goes into slow-mo and I got XP. Turns out, without me seeing or knowing, the guy for whatever reason decided to stop going on its 'fixed' path and went into my trap randomly.

Should I be concerned? Not so sure now.

Besides the NPCs, their glitches, faults, and outrageous rag-doll mechanics (inlcuding Lucius's as well when you're 'busted), the controls are something I want to touch on as well.

The using function is such a pain... Often times I mess up what I am doing and nearly get caught because I may have the wrong item equiped since if you pick up something, it switches to that.

The inventory is pretty spacious and all, but just trying to click on an item is a pain because often I click it and it makes me take it out almost immediately. I like the whole floating the item thing, but since it is not normal every NPC freaks out because I accidently have too many items and the inventory doesn't pause the game, so it's a rush to drop an item and quickly put away the one you are having float above your head, as if that is normal. Now I have to hide and switch items that I have equipped for the other so that if I were to be standing there like an idiot, no one will see something floating randomly next to me.

What happened to just holding stuff? Too cool for me!

Also... Is there a toggle for the sneak? It hurts my pinky to use the Left Crtl, holding it down while trying to figure out what I need, the inventory, power or item usage, and watch the patrols... Blargh.

Was this game rushed? Has no one even tested/try this game? Who the heck gave this signaI to release? I am very disappointed, but at least it gave me quite a few laughs when bodies randomly ragdoll everywhere... The first game at least was a lot better than this.

Not worth it though for full price. Maybe get it when it is worth $5 and you might get a small laugh out of it.

reviewText:
How can a sequel be this much worse than its predecessor? The game starts with a horrible and poorly made tutorial, then instead of some neat video sequences like the first game had, I had to suffer through some drawings with sound effects (the lazy mans video sequence, I suppose) and a not well thought-out plot being explained to me.

When I try to kill my first victim I have already realized that I have made a bad purchase as the game bugs itself and the victim start getting movement spasms instead of walking to its intended locations (what's up with the AI?!). I struggle in this area for a while, getting quite angry with the ONE looping sound effect from a madman in the background. He has one sound effect, and it literally plays about every twelth second!!!!
I can't use poison on the victim as the pills I had disappeared into the wall after I tried throwing them at an interactable ceiling hatch. Thankfully there are other, less buggy (but still buggy) ways to kill this victim, but at this point I just wish I could get my money back and never see this game again. I'm very sad to give this game a bad review as I really loved playing Lucius 1. I don't know what went wrong with this one, but I feel tricked. Obviously I should have watched a playthrough or a review on YouTube before wasting my money...

Lucius 1 was an incredible game, but I think they had a lower budget on its sequel, because the gameplay, sound effects and pretty much everything is a whole lot worse than it ever was. Or is this still in beta and I just didn't read the fine print?

EDIT:
I have to add to my review, because I was naive enough to give the game a second chance. Unfortunately that only served to remind me of how horrible this game actually is. reviewText: The main reason why I'm recommending the game is not because I adored the first, but because it has quite a lot of promise despite it's flaws. The plot of the story is just as basic as the first, but tries to over complicate itself with themes and character development that is lackluster and could have been slowed down for a more meaningful experience. Some moments, like when you first physically meet with Lucifer and when you meet up with your demon brother Isaac, leaves much to be desired. The story is rushed and feels as if, despite the gameplay and world being much more thought out, the story was put on the backburner and not given as much attention as it deserved. The story had very redeeming qualities that if it was given more time and effort, it would have been a lot more exciting. I really loved the idea of Lucifers sons fighting to be the favourite and doing so through a biblical demonic event. It moves past the personal struggles with his biological family and makes his demonic one more dynamic and almost human. For the gameplay, I felt that the fast paced and almost rushed qualities of the story rubbed off on it. The skills you obtain and the different ways that you can execute your targets were plentiful. You didn't have individual targets like the first game though, but whole floors full of people with you having a choice whether to only kill those you need to kill, or to kill them all to get more power. This is great, but the first games targets felt a lot more personal and gave you a chance to have an attachment to the character if you so wished to. If there would be a better balance between each aspect of the game and slowed it down, I think it would be much more successful of a game. Also, in regards to the endings hint towards a Lucius 3, it was a good ending at best and would have benefited with a little more flare. Perhaps using that tutorial map more so Lucifer could have more of a spotlight like he had in the first game would have done the trick. In my opinion I'd give the game a solid 6/10.

I honestly enjoy it more than the original Lucius. Sure the voice acting isn't as good, sure there are bugs, but the good stuff is just so good.

While the cutscenes in the first game are satisfying, getting to plan your own murders is a ton of fun. It also gives the game more replay value than its predecessor, since in that one it kind of loses its touch once you know how to beat every stage. I also adore the new skill tree system and the abilities to choose from. Especially since it doesn't force you to specialize yourself; as long as you kill enough people in every stage, you can probably max out the skill tree. And still, it sure is fun to play through the game with different play styles. Wanna start off as a mind controlling puppetmaster? Do that! Wanna become a master of telekinesis and toss people around? Do that! Wanna watch stuff burn? Do that!

Even though the game still steers your actions through the objectives, it still allows great freedom. Personally I'd love to see some kind of sandbox mode where you can choose between different locations to wreak havoc upon. The graphics have improved as well, so now I can finally look at Lucius's face without wanting to return to staring at the back of his head. The climax was also more impressive this time. It didn't just make you feel like an epic badass, it made you feel like an epic badass fighting a stronger epic badass. And that was fun.

But instead he was given a really ordinary low-pitched evil voice. Same with the devil. What was wrong with his old voice? I really liked that one.

reviewText:
This is a very fun, very unique game that improves on the original in all aspects. I got about 12 hours of pure enjoyment from it. Once I started playing, I couldn't stop until the whole gruesome thing was finished.

Unlike its predessor, there are multiple ways to kill each NPC. Many of these death setpieces are quite stunning. The game managed to impress me again and again with its  cartoonish violence and jovial, malevolent sense of humor. It rewards you for getting double and triple kills, and you'll find yourself looking for the most interesting and elaborate ways to kill the NPCs and move the plot along.

The game has is a mixture of adventure, stealth and action elements. The original was purely an adventure title. While it's true none of these aspects are executed masterfully, the unique nature of this game and its extremely entertaining premise more than makes up for the limitations of the engine.

Yes, it's still quite buggy but none of these bugs are gamebreaking. This game was made with a lot of love and it shows. It's well worth playing, bugs and all. Highly recommended.

reviewText:
After being in the Psych Ward for six months, the doctors decide shock treatment is the best for young Lucius and that’s where things go wrong. Sadly, you don’t get to see what happens next but judging by the blood on the walls and the dead body sitting next to you with the deliberator in his chest one can only imagine…

Unlike the first game where each person has a specific way they need to be sent to Hell, the sequel gives you the chance to explore the possibilities with a wide variety of deaths ranging from poisons, explosions, mind control murders, and flying oxygen tanks that are almost impossible to aim. My favorite kills so far have to be combining water on the floor with the deliberator, and using the nail gain which is pretty much a one-shot kill for each nail you have at your disposal. The hardest kill method is the oxygen tanks I’ve mentioned, because there’s no easy way to aim the sucks on the cart they use and the item keeps moving after you’ve stopped moving the cart. I could kill with a Dixie cup and some string easier than the tanks.

So far I’ve found an exploit; each of the deliberators can only be used once but saving and loading back to such saved file will reload the deliberator for use again, as well as tone down some of the way people look at you when it comes to suspicion – by the way you might be missing an item or two or need to do an objective again but that’s a small price to pay if it means you can essentially use a kill method near-indefinitely.

There’s a lot of things I like about this game but many of them are also things I liked about the first as well – such as the exploration, the music, and the immersion. Playing as the son of Satan is great and since he has no lines of any kind he doesn’t bore anyone with quotes cheesy one-liners. There’s a quote from Highlander in this one – imagine how much I laughed.

But there’s still some things that I didn’t like that returned as well. The music does seem to lag out from time to time and the voice narration is super quiet. Although the objectives are really clear, the kill methods seem to have some preferred victims, making it hard to kill that person with the keys if you’ve already used up your poisoned doughnuts.

The only two characters returning from the first game are the detective – the narrator but replaced with a different voice actor from the first – and Lucius’ human father but his role in the sequel can be summed up and being a vegetable on a hospital bed next to a life support machine than can be shut off at any time. That’s about it.

In short, I like Lucius 2 and will stand by the game in all its glory and faults just like I did its predecessor. I’m a little ways into chapter two and it doesn’t seem to have a very long game by the looks of it. According to Steam, there’s only about four more missions before the game is complete, but replay value is pretty high – there’s boggle heads to collect, kills to try out, skills to obtain, and cars to get hit by, so I can see myself playing this one for a while.


Now if you’ll excuse me I just reduced the population of Ludlow to zero and must explore to see if I missed something. To those playing this game, happy hunting!

(Fun fact: The town of Ludlow seems to have gotten in adult gizmos that are available at the General Store.)

I beat the first one and enjoyed it, so naturally I wanted to play the second. Well, I beat it. Meh. Without spoiling any details, when you beat the game, it just..... leaves you there awkwardly. When I should have been feeling the satisfaction of completion as the anti-christ, all I felt was the running-theme of frustration and confusion.

Pros:
-Sequel to good game
-Son of the Devil
-Killing people can be very fun
-The occasional creativity
-Can get achievment for killing nekkid man with a d-ildo up the booty-pipe
-Youtuber Cr1TiKaL voice acts an NPC (Job Gilman)

-LAG. Omg, the lag. Certain parts were worse than others
-The graphics in the first game were not the best. That said, I feel like the graphics in this one were a step down

Unfortunately I would not reccommend this game as a stand-alone game. If you enjoyed the first one, proceed with caution. There are absolutely fun moments. But for the most part, it's a flawed game.

Okay. There's a few things I really want to say about this game (and developers) that (depending on the person) may be good or bad.

When I first purchased the game, this game was practically unplayable. It crashed 49/50 times and there seemed to be no fix in sight. Nothing I tried worked and I found myself becoming increasingly impatient and ever-so-close to wanting to demand for some sort of compensation. However, that mindset quickly changed with the patience and amazing communication of the devs that helped me finally fix this issue. So I'm definitely giving Devs 5/5

Game play, it's pretty simple; simple physics with the way objects are thrown and the force of the throw can determine whether something potentially lethal (chemicals) will break and kill your unsuspecting victim or just chill on the floor (or whatever place it lands on). The story is simple. Maybe a bit too simple since the main objective of this game seems to be killing everyone in as many ways as you can think of possible. I'm giving that a 3/5 for game play since it /does/ get a bit repetitive after awhile. Also, my first time playing through this game, even though I use the lifeline, somehow, I still end up getting a game over instead of memorywiping the person that busts Lucius.

The objectives are pretty repetitive; collect keys, unlock doors and break things to complete your objective (and kill specific people). The story of the game can pretty much be summarized in a few words: Escape the hospital, kill your competition for Father/Satan's affection and the right to kinda be like Satan's favorite son that gets to sit by him while the world burns. Story: 2/5

So I guess I give this game a 3/5

1. This game was pretty freaken broken when it first came out. BUT the devs are all working very hard to fix the issues one by one.

2. The Devs are all super nice people. They kept me updated with possible fixes until the issue of game crashing was fixed.

3. I love the fact that I get to be the antichrist and murder people. (Basically, I love the Omen and the concept of the two Lucius games) I know the first game was definitely parallel to the Omen in story but Lucius II had an original storyline in continuation of the first game.

reviewText:
Have you ever wanted to play the son of the devil? Do you have this desire to find creative ways to kill all that stand in your way from achieving your goals of showing the devil how much you love him? Well if you said yes this is the game for you.

Lucius II: The Prophecy, developed by Shiver Games, takes a page right out of the movie The Omen, and puts you in the shoes of Lucius an unassuming boy who has a very dark past and intent. You will find yourself navigating through a hospital, as well as a local town. Somehow you have lost your devilish powers, and you are going to be hell bent on getting them back. There's only one issue, you are going to have to first escape the hospital. Once you do that there's a little twist and perhaps some competition waiting for you.

Graphically this game looks great, it uses the Unity engine, and you can definitely tell that it uses it well. I was a bit concerned about the random male nudity that was sprinkled through the game, especially a specific locked bathroom door scene, but other than that the game looked great.

I just wish I could say the same about the game mechanics. There's definitely the option to customize your evil powers so that you can play to your strengths, but there are definitely some skills that once I got them I never used them, or I could never figure out how to use them. Basically the first fire skill till the end of the game I couldn't figure out how to use.

There's also the fact that when you pick up items you automatically levitate them in your hand, my problem is I really wish that items/weapons that you use that could use an actual touch were held. It just looked strange to use the nail gun, or the water container as it is suspended in air.

Speaking of suspending in air the whole throw mechanic was just strange, would it have been too much to ask to just have a straight shot with gravity taking effect after some distance instead of the constant rainbow throw that the game gave you. It was just a little awkward to aim for something straight in front of you or right above you, if you were standing close.

The music in the game definitely gave you that anti-christ game feeling. I'm not saying screaming demons, or anything, but it definitely fit with The Omen type of feel. I did find it interesting that the voice overs in game tended to fade in and out which made me thankful there was subtitles so that I could actually pick up on what was being said.

This game definitely showed that there are many many ways to kill, and I have to say that the MOST difficult part of the entire game was the beginning, I spend hours trying to figure out how to kill people in the hospital because I accidentally screwed up a chance to kill someone. Hell I ended up possessing people's minds and had them continuously walk into the open elevator shaft because I couldn't get anything else to work.

I do wish I was able to play the first one so that I could get the whole story, but then again this is probably a game with three parts as this game will give you a cliffhanger at the end. I can say that you can jump right into the game from this chapter, thanks to the openning credits.

In the end this game is frustrating, feels clunky, and there are certain things that aren't 100% clear on what you are supposed to do that will leave you scratching your head and maybe ultimately reaching out to the gaming community to figure out a solution. So with that being said this game gets a 7.1 out of 10.

reviewText:
I'm not sure exactly why everyone is hating on this game. Personally I enjoyed every minute of it and will continue playing long after I have finished. There are only a few games in my entire Steam library that I have actually sat down and played from beginning to end; and fewer still that I actually go back to. With most games I usually get bored after awhile and start playing something else, but Lucius II kept me thorougly entertained during my entire playthrough. Yes it is a short game, but each level is a sandbox that provides unlimited diversion. Yes, there are bugs, but I have not encountered any that were gamebreaking. I only crashed once in the many hours I've played, and the other bugs I encountered were mostly minor, such as a missing icon or broken camera angle when climbing up to a rooftop.

I have only a few gripes, and nothing too serious to keep anyone from enjoying this game. The first is a lack of kill animations. Whenever you sucessfully kill an NPC they will usually turn into a ragdoll and fall on the floor. The kills are still interesting and unique and should delight most players, but the lack of detailed death animations kinda makes that elaborate setup you worked so hard on seem disappointing. Another problem is the AI in general. It still needs a lot of work. Sometimes an NPC will get stuck in a position or have trouble reacting to the bait you left on the floor, or sometimes they will just sit in mid air. They also do not react when an explosion just rocked the next room. This brings me to my final complaint which is the overall unpolished feel to the game. As players have suggested, it feels rushed. You'll notice a decline in quality as soon as you watch the cutscenes, which are nothing more than paper dolls with a character narrating. I don't know if they were going for an aesthetic appeal with this or just cutting costs. When compared to the cinematic cutscenes of the first game it really feels like they opted for the less expensive route.

Personally I'm not bothered by the cheap changes or the small bugs and beta AI, but now I cannot decide which game I prefer. I love the first game, and that one actually feels like a finished product, but the lack of variety really turns me off. After you finish that game there's really no reason to go back to it unless you are achievement hunting. Lucius II, however, lets you plan your murders, set up traps, and kill in any order. On the other hand, in Lucius I the kill scenes were so gruesomely gratifying. It's really hard to decide which game is better, but I think that once the devs finally iron out all the problems in Lucius II I'm sure most fans will be happy with it. There's an amazing sequel to Lucius here, you just have to dig through all the mess to find it.

(Oh yeah, and the final boss is a direct replica of Malachai from Children of the Corn. Too awesome!)

reviewText:
I really wanted to like Lucius II -- I love the idea of setting devious traps for the unwary, and the unique story certainly has a lot of potential. However, there are so many game-breaking bugs, poorly designed interfaces, performance issues, and control scheme nightmares that I cannot recommend this game to anyone.

For example, there is a sequence where Lucius must use a shotgun. Simple, right? No. The process goes like this:
1. Collect the shotgun and shells by aiming the reticule at them, pressing E, and then pressing G (yes, really).
2. Go to the inventory screen and drag the shells onto the shotgun. The game does not pause while you're in this window, despite the fact that you can't see any of the action, so it's very likely you'll get mercilessly ravaged while you attempt to do this.
3. Double-click the shotgun to equip it. Urghh, it didn't work. Double-click again. Double-cli- Oh, there it goes.
4. Fire twice before having to repeat the clumsy process all over again.

Additionally, it's possible to get into states where a level becomes uncompletable -- for example, on many of the hospital floors, there are keys you need to pick up in order to progress. These keys can disappear or become lodged somewhere out of sight, and the level has to be restarted.

There's a fair amount of slowdown in this game, which is odd considering the fact that the graphics aren't anything to write home about. The final battle is particularly bad about this -- particle effects grind the game to a halt. Expect freezes, too.

There's a great number of smaller issues that the developers surely must have noticed -- for example, the inventory screen often claims containers are 100% full when they're actually empty, volume levels fluctuate at random from scene to scene, and when Lucius drops objects, they hover in midair instead of falling to the ground.

Add to that the fact that no one proofread any of the text, and you can clearly see that this is another half-baked Unity game released on Steam far too early. I hope that Lucius II becomes playable someday, but for now, it's impossible to justify spending $20 for the dubious pleasure of playing this frustrating game. Overall, it's a great concept, but it feels like it's still in alpha.

reviewText: This is truly one of the most marvelous games I have ever played. The storyline is riveting from the beginning all the way to the final conflict.  You feel mesmerised by Lucius as he conducts his reign of death, There were so many ingenius tools and means by which Lucius conducted his business.You absolutely never got bored for even a second. The game is two chapters and they are both lengthy.You move from Hospitals to Research Facilities to exploring the dark town of Ludlow with many other distinct and original areas in between. The graphics were superb. It is extremely rare in this day and age to find a game that pushes the limits as this one does. At times outlandish and sometimes hilarious this game goes to the brink of well mannered society and bumps it up a notch. I like that. I like it a lot. People need to be challenged at times and this game certainly does that. Just the sheer number of different buildings and areas to explore was extraordinary! The creativity created for the death scenes was obviously well thought out. There were literally hundreds of different items that could be utilised to achieve the task at hand. I'm not sure anyone could really say enough about the storyline. It was absolutely a masterpiece from beginning to end. It blended together magnificently. I felt the character. I felt his mission. I understood the root core of his being. In conclusion,I would like to say to the developers; I certainly hope there will be a Lucius III. Also,leave Lucius as the young boy he was in your next addition. This one unique aspect seems to trademark this young fellow. We don't want to see him grow up. Also,consider giving him a voice to speak. I believe this would add tremendously to the next addition.

reviewText:
To improve upon the original Lucius wouldn't have been a daunting nor difficult task, there were plenty of design mistakes that plagued the debut effort. Apart from being less linear and providing more variety and tools for dispatching victims, Lucius II is everything a sequel shouldn't be. Filled to the brim with bugs and glitches that constantly drag down gameplay, the AI is beyond a joke and incredibly easy to exploit, the only challenge comes from the infuriating, broken mechanics. The arid story takes you through a range of mundane and characterless locations, it also features the most nonthreatening devil in video game history.

Slaughtering the developers with a nail gun was quite cathartic, and very telling, this feels like a product of self-loathing.

3/10
